page.title: 19NATURAL HISTORY
page.content: Man's activities have created a number of havens for wildlife in the arable landscape. The verges of the A2(T) road and the steep embankment of the Dover_Deal railway cutting are free from man's interference. The former is a fine hunting ground for hawks and the latter lined with buckthorn,elder and beech is a perfect habitat for rabbits. 19 runs were found in one 80m stretch. The trackbeds of the disused Lt. Railway from Martim Mill to the cliffs are overgrown and are ideal for burrowing mammals. The presence of droppings and shotgun cartridges how numerous the rabbits and foxes must be. Scattered around the area are chalk pits from which flints were once removed. Useless to the farmer thses areas provide small islands for wildlife in the sea of cereal crops. The predominant insects are woodlice.
